Isaac   Jonesboro Union Co ILL
Dec 1 1851
Jonesboro Union Co. Illinois
Sabbath, Nov. 30. 1851

 Dear Antoinette   Your letter of November eleventh reached me on the twenty sixth, making the journey in considerable less than the usual time, and as usual gladdening my heart not a little. The same evening, by the same Mail, came also letters from Bangor, Brothers and Sisters. A very comfortable preparation for Thanksgiving to be sure.  Yet, I think, if I had not been unusually or at least extremely busy, I should have been on that day lonesome, or almost homesick. Thanksgiving is not at all observed here; in fact no one seemed to remember the day; and it is a day when, you know, a New Englander especially thinks of home and its surroundings, of relatives and friends, and more than ever longs to be with them.
Completed

I am extremely glad to hear that you Father & Mother had
so completely recovered their health, and hope it will continue.
You write in sight of the snow covered ground, sparkling
and white.  How I want to see it.  Here the people are complaining
bitterly of cold weather, but it is only that there are frosty mornings
and those not all the time.  The weather here
for a few weeks past has been much like our September
and early October weather at the East, only with more
of rain and clouds.  There is little of our clear bright
Autumnal weather, the finest of the year, as I think it is
in New England.  Perhaps a bright frosty morning, but
cloudy ere night, and about half the time more or
less rainy.  It seems a sort of rainy season after
the long dry season of the Summer & early fall.
Still I like the weather now better than earlier in the
season.  The really cold rainy weather is not so unpleasant
the air seems clearer and purer, and one is not so
uncomfortable under clothing that will keep one dry.
You speak of my Sabbath privileges, and I certainly
almost envy those who enjoy such as I like.
Yet here in Jonesboro the privileges of the Sabbath are probably
better than the average throughout the country, certainly
much better than usual in Southern Illinois.
There are two pretty tolerably good houses of worship
The principal is the Baptist.  The Baptist Church membership
is quite a large one, numbering between two and three
hundred, though so scattered & living out of the village that
only fifty or seventy five is a frequent audience there.
Completed

The Baptist Minster is doubtless well supported, and 
is probably among the best of his Sect in Southern Illinois.
He is an Exhorter rather than a demoniser, and I cannot
say that I like his preaching much.
The Methodist Minister I like better.  He is a regular thorough
going disciple of John Wesley, zealous, enthusiastic
and untiring, but I presume can preach twenty sermons
in a week just as well as two.  He has not much Education
of course, and is apparently rather mediocre except in
zeal, and in that the Methodists as a Sect appear to 
excel.  In some respects I like the Methodists much
and on the whole, I think better than the Baptists.
But my favorite preacher is rather a big old
German "Father Krack" who preaches here once a
month.  He belongs to the Lutheran Church; His English
is not by any means perfect, but he is a man
of large intellect as well as person, and I judge well
educated.  His preaching is the best here.
The Methodist Circuit rider preaches here but one half
the Sabbath, Father Krack, one fourth, the Baptist
preaches here all the time.  Today at that church
however preached or tried to a Baptist Colporteur, he
did little else however than shout, and I enjoyed
it but very little.
The Sabbath services here are always at Eleven o clock
and at candlelight, never in the afternoon.
So I usually spend some part at least of the afternoon very
pleasantly in writing letters, either to you or to Mother
Completed

and Brothers & Sisters.
I must tell you too how I spend the week days.
I breakfast before daylight, then mount my horse,
and ride off into the country from two to ten miles
spend the day in the woods, looking out and locating
the Rail Road route, and at night ride back to town, perhaps
after dark, then spend an hour or two in R.R Office, recording
the business of the day, or planning that of tomorrow.
These Southern Illinois woods are very different from ours
in New England, so heavy and thick and tall, Poplar,
and Cypress, and Gum and Sycamore with the Oak &
Hickory, little or no underbrush, but abundance of
climbing vines of various kinds, some very beautiful
Well, it is time for me to be going to evening
meeting, and I must stop writing, with much
love and good evening.
Sincerely
I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro Union Co. Ill.
Nov. 24, 1851
Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois.
Thursday, Nov. 20, 1851
Dear Antoinette
Your letter of Oct. 28, was joyfully received two days since.  I intended to write that day, but press of business prevented.  Col. Mason had just arrived here, had very short time to stay, and I had considerable business to attend to and settle up.  I have now been relieved of my temporary charge of the Division Engineership, after retaining its honor and dignity -- or rather care and responsibility -- longer than I expected, on account of Col. Mason delaying his return.
The new incumbent, L. W. Ashley has also arrived, so that I am again one under authority, though still have power, like the centurion, to say to one, "go" and he goeth, and to another 'do this' and he doeth it.  I had hoped, if I decided to remain here this winter, to be able to go East for a few weeks at least.
But in the present press of business here, I cannot get away.  I have got fairly enlisted in the Location of this Division.  No one can take my place, and I must stay until January at least.  I told Col. Mason I would start in January then.  But he told me I would get to Boston just about as soon to wait & start in March!
I suppose there is hardly any such thing as decent travelling in this region when the river navigation and the easiest way to get East from here in the Winter is to go to New
Completed

Orleans, and go around by Water.
So I suppose I am likely to be here for the Winter
and I cannot well help it.  Perhaps it is for the
best; but I tell you I am lonesome here.
If I could have got away to the East, by this time, or
better a Month since, and persuaded you to come
back with me, I think I could have been very well
contented here, to spend the winter at least.
But, we must make the best of it as it is
I am somewhat troubled though in thinking of the Winter
irregularity of the Mails.  If letters are irregular and
perhaps lost, why - why must write the more of them.
You must not be anxious about my health.
The Winter, you know, is the healthy season here.
I am getting strong, hearty, and fat.  In a month
or two more, the prospect is, I should hardly be known
for the same man I was a month or two since.
Besides I have got so now that I do not fear an
attack of the ague as I did.  I know better how to
deal with it, and could throw it off at once, on
the first symptoms.  Still, I must say, I have such a 
dislike of the miserable disease that I am likely to 
be pretty careful to avoid it, and I presume shall
have nothing more of the kind.
As you mention there is undoubtedly a great deal
of suffering with the Ague, among poor people and
far from a Physician.  I see whole families here
who are about the most miserable beings I ever saw.
Completed

Still those here who are able to take proper care of
their health are rarely seriously troubled.
The Sabbath day on which you wrote hoping I was not
sick that day, I was really very near sick!  having
been exposed to rain a few days before and was threatened
with an ague attack.
Last Sabbath there was a great meeting at Jonesboro.
the Sabbath Convention of Southern Illinois.  I commenced
on Thursday, but I was out of town and could
not be there till Sat Eve.  There were many Ministers
present of many different denominations, and some were
really quite superior ones;  real western orators through most
of them.  I was almost amused at times to hear some
of them, thoroughly educated men, perhaps 'raised' at the East,
evidently learned, and certainly eloquent, but fully western
in their style; I suppose they feel obliged in a measure 
to adapt themselves to their audience.
I enjoyed that Sabbath very much.  Usually however I must
say that I look towards the East considerably on that
day, in spite of my habitual contentedness with the present
It seems you had Winter when you wrote,
nearly a month ago, and here there has been
but comparatively little frost as yet; though to be
sure the people complain bitterly of cold weather,
as soon at least as nights begin to be cool.
I suppose though there will be some snow and cold
weather here in course of the season.
I hope your Fathers health is well established for
Completed

Your account of tracing lines in the woods
was quite amusing.  I can hardly say however
that you ought to have acquired very great reputation
as an Engineer.
As for your keeping school this Winter, of course
you must exercise your own discretion, and if
you really think it necessary to your enjoyment of
course I shall not object, but I should think you
might be full as comfortable at home.
But for advice, I must do as you do by me, say 'do as 
you think best.
But it is getting very late, my time is limited,
and I must stop, with much love to all and
especially to yourself.
Sincerely
I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro Union Co. Ill.
Dec. 10 1851
Jonesboro Union Co. Illinois
Tuesday, Dec. 9, 1851
Dear Antoinette
Your kind letter of Nov. 22, is just received.  I am going tomorrow morning to Cairo and that region for a week or ten days.  So I will write a bit tonight, though I have little time, as it is already rather late in the evening.
Your hopes that the winter here may be one of health appear likely to be realized.  It is apparently quite healthy now every where here.  The miserable sallow wretched ague stricken countenances of the natives {as they seemed six or eight weeks ago} are getting to be quite tolerably healthy looking, more like those of comfortable human beings.  My own health I believe is getting quite firmly established, and I really enjoy the kind of weather we have here lately very much -- cool, bracing, frosty.  I fear however we may not have much of it.  The winder is often only a sort of rainy season, or if snow falls, at all, it is only worse melting into this Mud in a day or two.
There has been no snow as yet, hardly to Whiten the ground for a half hour.  We are hoping however to get the out of door work pretty much completed for the winter within a
Completed

week or two; or at least so much that we can take our time for whatever else there is to be done.
I am truly very much obliged to you for the extract from your sermon book.  A real Congregation Sermon is valuable indeed here, I assure; and I judge your abstract of one is worth more than any I often hear here.  Why, I shall get along very tolerally if I do not get a chance to go to Church next Sabbath. 
I hear from Maine very regularly nowadays  My Mother's health appears to be very good.  She spends the winter in Bangor, going out to Milo a few weeks in September and October only since last spring.  Sister Lucy's health they think to be rapidly improving, comparatively so that is.  She has been unwell and feeble you know for a long time.
I expect I shall be late in the morning if I stop to write longer tonight.
I seem to be somehow established here now for the Winter, but you much expect to see me in New Hampshire pretty early in the Spring.  I do not know but I am becoming popular with the new Division Engineer, and he may try to keep me here, if possible next season, doubtless he will, and I could do well here, perhaps far better than to go elsewhere.
Completed

What do you think about it?
Would you be willing to come out here next Spring?
It will probably depend in great measure upon that.
You must write about it and advise me.
Love to Father & Mother
And to yourself especially.
Sincerely 
I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac  Jonesboro Union Co. Ill.
Jan 16  1852
Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois
Wednesday Jan 14. 1852
Dear Antoinette
Your kind letter of Dec. 19, I received on my arrival in Town last night. It had been here two or three days I suppose. I have been away for a week, up in the Prairies, at Mt Hawkins my last summer's home, and out to Murphysboro, Pinkneyville, and Nashville, the County - Shire Towns, to obtain certain land records from the County offices. I have got so that I enjoy riding horseback very much, even in the cold weather. The past week has been quite cold and stormy, unusually so for this Country, more snow has fallen than often in whole winters, and all the Suckers are very much curled up by the cold. But I have enjoyed it very much, it has seemed almost like New England weather, though the Cold weather here would be warm for winter weather there.
I have not been up at Mt Hawkins since I left there last September, and the visit was quite pleasant. Mrs Roots called me rather a bad boy for not coming to see my "Mother" oftener. I believe she was as kind to me when sick as a Mother could be. The prairies I find look rather dreary in winter, especially when a cold wintry wind is blowing the snow across them. Even the quails and prairie chickens hardly seem to enjoy it.
Completed

I am much obliged for your copy of Rail Road News. If I were now in New England, I would perhaps try to get a place upon that New York and Boston Air Line R.R. Probably however there would be but little chance. There is so little Rail Road building or surveying going on in New England now, and so many there out of business that there is little chance for one without personal acquaintance or favor of those engaged in it.
The time for Engineering Employment in N.E. is mostly passed. In New York State there is considerable doing now, under the Nine Million Canal Enlargement, but Canal Engineering I do not consider my business and do not like it either.  The present field for RailWay Engineers seems decidedly to be in the Western States and here a great field is just opening.
Mr Ashley, our new Div. Eng. here, laughs at the idea of remaining at the East now. I like Mr Ashley very well. He is a regular Yankee, though he has been four or five years in the west. Mrs Ashley is quite a pleasant lady, an Episcopalian. They have three little children. If I will stay here, I can have a very favorable situation, living at Jonesboro, have charge of thirty miles of road through this hilly Country of Union & Pulaski Counties without going into the unhealthy region of Cairo at all. I do not know but I had better conclude to remain here. It certainly appears best both for my present emolument, and future prospects in every way.
Completed

If so, will you consent to come and live here next summer? Suppose I come East for a week or two early in the Spring, and you come back with me, say early in March at least? I really think we can be very comfortable here. This hilly country at and about Jonesboro is considered the healthiest part of Illinois. It certainly has been the past season, much more so than the north part of the State.
We have a Presbyterian Minister here now. Rev Mr Stewart lately of Greenville Bond Co. He is quite an able man, perhaps I wrote something about him at the I.I. Bible Convention. He is sent here by the Presbytery {New School} as a Missionary, to build up Presbyterianism in this part of the State, and especially in Jonesboro, the most important part.
I like him very well, and I presume he would like much to have me stay here. By the way, he calls this one of the healthiest places in the whole western country, and he ought to know, having always lived in these States, -- is native of Ohio, his wife though is from Massachusetts, Westfield, I believe.
Last Sabbath I spent at Mt Hawkins, at Mr Roots place.
You enquire if the failure of the $15.000.000 Loan will affect the progress of this Road. The failure will prevent the immediate completion of the Road, but not prevent its progress: And this Southern portion, being the most difficult part, and at the end too, will probably go on about the same any way.
Completed

You enquire how we do for Dinner in the Woods. Sometimes we carry it, sometimes get it brought out to us, and sometimes go without.
We often have pretty good Pic Nics under those tall forest trees, and if the far is rough, good appetites make up abundantly any deficiency.
The forests here are certainly magnificent. They are too, much more comfortable however in the Winter than Summer, being free from Misquitoes, and various such like little pests, which often diminish one's enjoyment quite seriously in Summer.
The Woods are full of birds here too in Winter, apparently more so than in summer; probably because then they are hidden by the very dense foliage.
There are here in Winter, Most of our N.E. Summer birds, and many unknown there, Among others a beautiful bright red bird, Cardinal grosbeak, I judge. Also an astonishing variety of Woodpeckers.
Well, it is past Eleven. I must quit.
Much love to Father & Mother & Antoinette especially. I hope you will write immediately on receipt of this. and what you think of Illinois as a home,
Good night
Sincerely

I.S.
Completed

Isaac Marseilles, Pulaski Co., Ill
Caledonia
Feb. 4 1852

                                                                                              Near Marseilles, Pulaski Co. Illinois
                                                                                                Sabbath. Feb. 1, 1852

Dear Antoinette

                        It seems some time since I have received a letter from you, or in fact from any one. There are doubtless letters for me on the way, or in store for me somewhere.

The Winter here has been unusually severe, the rivers obstructed with ice, and all communication very much interrupted, much more than is usual even here in common winters.
There had been no Mail from abroad received at Jonesboro for a week or two before I left there on Monday last. And the Mail agents said they could hardly expect any for a week or two longer. Still the weather has been so very warm & pleasant the past week that I think the mails may have arrived there, and on that account am sorry that I did not get back last night as I had expected.

   I wrote to you in my last letter that I had almost finally decided to remain here this summer, or part of the summer, and wrote I believe how good a situation I could have here, and how comfortably and pleasantly I may be situated at Jonesboro; and inviting you to be ready to come out here with me early in the Spring.
Completed

I am now making all preparations for spending the Summer comfortably, getting my work done up well, the Line all staked out and ready for the Contractors and Workmen, especially on this end of my Line fartherest from Jonesboro; so that if I have good Assistants I shall not have to visit it so often.
I came down here last Monday, and intend to remain down this way most of the time for a week or two longer. When I came down here the ground was thoroughly covered with Snow and quite cold weather, as it had been all the Month nearly. Since then it has turned warm and every thing looks like Sprung in New England.
It seems strange to a Yankee to see clear starlit nights in January to warm to freeze at all, or even harden the soft moist snow. So it has been the past week. I have found a very pleasant and comfortable stopping place here, with Dr. Arter, a physician of very extensive practice, who has finely established himself here upon the most Southern point of high ground in the State, and eight or ten miles from both Cairo & Caladonia, in which villages is most of his practice.
Dr. Arter says there is no more healthy place in the world than here, and refers for illustration to his own family. And certainly I never saw a more healthy fine looking family of children than his appear. He has lived here for many years, and his children were all, as the western phrase is, "raised" here.
Did I write to you about my horse? I have bought
Completed

a horse which pleases me very much; very quick and high spirited, but if rightly treated as gentle as a lamb, though so playful that I hardly dare trust any one else to do any thing with him/
Did you ever ride horse back?
I am very fond of a good horse, and still more so since I have got to riding horseback so much. Here riding horseback is almost the only method either for business or pleasure.
I am afraid my last letter was delayed in reaching you by the hard weather, and I am extremely anxious to hear from you as soon as possible, in order to know what you think about spending the summer in Illinois. I think there can be no trouble on the score of health. In order to be sure, we have made all arrangements to be able to get away from the work, through the sickly season, of August and September, leave here entirely for a month or two, and spend the time in travelling perhaps, at the North.
I think I shall do right in deciding to remain here, but am anxious to learn your view of the Matter. Business appears plainly to call upon me to remain here. I can do better to remain here, probably both for the present and the future. I can probably lay up about a thousand dollars a year above all expenses here now, at present wages, and that is not found every where for young men now a days, saying nothing of the prospect of increase of salary.
Completed

I have just now returned from Meeting, and looking at the rambling scrawl I wrote before going out I conclude it does not seem much like a Sabbath exercise. However the meeting was, I had almost said, not much better. There were three Minister present and all took part in the services, two of them preaching, as they called it. They were so ignorant, ignored not only of books, and what is called learning; that, I know, for I heard it, some men can preach, and preach efficacously therefore well, without, but ignorant really of everything ignorant even of human nature, of themselves, of the bible, and I almost thought of religion. It pained me to see such blind leaders of the blind.
The Church is Baptist, very small and poor, as well as ignorant, but no doubt containing some good and spiritually wise. Some perhaps would relish no other or better preaching than that they had today.
A Sabbath spent in a place like this makes me think of Jonesboro as really quite desirable.
I have not received any letters from home for some weeks, and am anxiously expecting them.
All well well at least letters, Sister Lucy very much better than last summer.
I am hoping to hear from you very soon, as well as often. My best respect to Father & Mother and much love to yourself.

                                                                                                      Sincerely
                                                                                                                   I.S.
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro, Union Co. Ill.
Feb. 9. 1852                                                                                               Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois

                                                                                                                   Sabbath, Feb. 7. 1852

Dear Antoinette

                   Your kind letter of Jan 5-10th. was received by me last evening. I had been out of Town all the week or I should have received it a little sooner I suppose; But our Mails here have been very irregular and very much delayed this winter. The Winter has been very unusually sever, and all Travelling very much interrupted. The past week or two though has been very warm, almost as warm as summer it has seemed to me. The frost & snow went off in a hurry the rivers are all free from ice, and the navigation uninterrupted, So we may now expect regular Mails. Your last letters have been very long on the road; this last almost a whole month. Probably mine have been equally delayed. If so I fear you may have been rather impatient in waiting for them.

I wrote to you last from Marseilles, a week ago, I believe. Since then I have once almost made up my mind to start for the East at once, though the journey would be rather unpleasant at this season, with considerable staging, and some risk of detention. I am getting to be very much troubled as, we do not get get any orders as to what is to be done here this season - only that we must be 'All ready'. We may, on the one hand, be called upon any day to put the work under control at once, and make us all busy; or on the other hand the orders may be as
Completed

suddenly to discharge all subordinates, and shut up shop for time. So I know not what to do for myself. It is decidedly unsafe for me to leave until the matter is decided somehow. If there should come a decision to put under contract at once and I away from here, it would be a Scrape of the worst sort, Or if the work is to be stopped for the summer I should not want to leave until then or till I could be ready for it. I talked with Mr. Ashley about it last night, and he thinks it would hardly do to leave now; but says we may all depend upon a long vacation in the Summer whether the work goes on at once or not. From the Nature of the country it has been decided not to keep the work progressing, or the Irish laborers at work through the hot season.
However we are hoping to hear very soon some decision of the Directors as to what is to be done this Season. It may come any day. It is rather inconvenient to have the management & Direction of a Rail Road so far off. For a while this Winter New York has been nearly a month distant from Southern Illinois. 
The winter it seems has been very severe all over the country. I see in all the Newspapers accounts of extremely cold weather and great storms everywhere, not only in this country, but in Europe also.
It seems you have your full share upon Dunbarton hill this Winter of both cold and storm.
I think it would be quite a pleasure to me to see a real good snowdrift, one of your fifteen feet drifts for instance.
Completed

I wish I could have been at your annual Festival at Dunbarton & I should have enjoyed it very much. How comfortable those New England winters are. How much of social pleasure and real home enjoyment, which I believe the people here know little of.
I believe I wrote to you something of the Meeting I attended last Sabbath at the Shiloh Baptist Church Today I have fared much better; in the forenoon at the Baptist Church, where preached a Colporteur named Kelly, not much of a preacher to be sure, and with some thing of an impediment in his voice, but I presume a very good man, and I enjoyed the sermon vert well. This Evening, I have heard my favorite, the good old German Lutheran Father Krack. I really like to hear his preaching very well. He preaches here though only one Evening in a Month now. I believe I wrote you that there was a Presbyterian Minister here now, and a very good one too Rev. Mr. Stewart lately of Grenville Bond Co. Ill. The field of his labor however is I believe all Southern Illinois almost, and he does not seem to preach here very often. I have not seen him now for some time, as I have been out of Town so much.
Next Saturday & Sabbath the Methodist Quarterly Meeting is to be held there. And I intend to be present of possible. Did you ever attend a Methodist Quarterly Meeting? I attended one once held in a Big Barn down in Maine which I thought was one of the very best meetings I ever knew of. Did you know I came very near being a Methodist once? I liked the Methodists very much at that time; and so still, somewhat.
Completed

I am afraid you will hardly have patience to read my letters if I write so much, so long and so often, and so poorly besides.
I wish I could write that I would be in New Hampshire the first of March or sooner. No one can tell how much I want to go at once. The time seems so long.
Well I shall certainly go as soon as I can.
And in the mean time shall keep writing letters, and hope you will do the same.
It is getting late and I must close with much love and respect to Father & Mother and yourself especially

                                                                       Sincerely  I.S.
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro Union Co. Ill.
Feb. 23d 1852  

                                                                                                               Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                                               Sabbath. Feb. 22. 1852

Dear Antoinette

                                          Your letter of Feb. 5, was received last evening. And one of an earlier date Jan. 23d came to hand two or three days before, and is still unreplied to. I last wrote to you I think two weeks ago today.

You suppose Early Spring comes earlier in Southern Illinois than it does among the Granite Mountains of New Hampshire. I think it does. At any rate the weather here since the last week of January has been that of Spring, as warm mostly as New England May at least. The ground looks very green already in many places, especially the Wheat fields. The buds are swelling rapidly, and some of the earlier forest trees & shrubs have already "hung all their lapels forth" Yet there is very likely more cold and frost, perhaps more snow even, before the first of April. Though there has been any frost but two or three times only since the last week of Jan.
I have been in much trouble for some time, as to when I shall, or can, go East. I did think to start by about this time, but it seems I can not get away all any rate until we after we can learn the decision of the R.R. Company, as to what is to be done here this Season and how it is to be done
Completed

And we do not as yet receive any direction, though long since expected, except simply "Be in readiness} Of course, it does not do for me to leave upon any pretext. It is getting to be so late too; if the work is to on here this Season, it must be commenced before long, and it will not do for me to be absent until that time.
So I am waiting, Waiting - getting really somewhat out of patience; but at the same time getting every thing in the best possible state of preparation to leave. In fact I have been hard at work all the time, and should be if ever so long. Mr. Ashley tells me I must almost unavoidably wait till summer, and rehearses the many conveniences and necessities of delay, and what he calls the impracticability of going East at this Season.
But I refuse as yet to give it up, and if our "Orders" should arrive tomorrow, I should probably start on the next day. I did expect to get to New Hampshire and Maine before the first of March. If I do not get there this Spring, I shall count the days until my promised Summer vacation, I assure you.
"My Minister" preached today, Mr. Stewart, the Presbyterian Clergyman of whom I wrote to you, and I had quite a treat you may be certain. He has preached here in town but a few times, having no Church, and not wishing to interfere with the regular services of the other Ministers. Today the Baptist Minister is sick and Mr. Stewart has taken his place. He is really quite a preacher for this country, and I believe is very much liked by the people here.
Completed

I have just now returned from Evening Meeting. Mr. Stewart preached, and I think his discourse was even better than in the forenoon, or than I ever heard from him. His text was "Today, if ye will hear his voice etc." I was pleased to see him, with true western feeling, come down from the pulpit, and take his stand in the open space before the desk, saying he could have more liberty there. and when he got into the open space, he certainly did not lack for gesture or action, though quite dignified withal. 
By the way, thinking of Oratory, I cannot tell how much I want to see & hear Kossuth. If I were at leisure I travel five hundred miles, & give fifty dollars, just to see the man. I do regard him as not only the greatest Orator, but the greatest man now living in the world. Is he not the greatest spirit of the age? And if his life is spared, destined to the greatest influence over the age & world?  If so, what a blessing that he is such a man; so different from many Master Spirits of other ages, for instance. Napoleon Bonaparte, whose influence was so great in the beginning of this century.

 You are very right in surmising that I am proud of My State. Has not Maine done nobly? May others soon follow its example. Every letter I get from there contains something about the success and beneficial working of the Liquor Law, or as it is called "The Maine Law." 

I am very much hoping that Old Massachusetts will pass a similar law this Winter. What is New Hampshire about to do upon the Subject? I see that New York and even some of the Western States are agitating the Subject. The Quart Law of this state of Illinois is one step. That has been very much opposed however here.
Completed

you mention in your letter that you would like to know more definitely about what our situation and arrangements will be here. I have thought of that considerable, that it would be pleasant to you to know more about it, beforehand, I have thought about it, I say, & wished to write all I could to you, but could think of nothing definite as a conclusion. It is decided I suppose that if I stay here, my headquarters are to be in Jonesboro, but how I am to be situated must depend almost entirely upon the decision by the R.R. Co. about this part of the Road, when, how fast, and in what manner, the work is to be done.  Perhaps it will be best to "Board" at first. {We could have quite a comfortable place here, where I now board} though I have altogether too fond an idea of "My own fireside" to prefer that as a permanent arrangement.
However, all that matter and every thing connected with it must be left almost or quite entirely to you.  An Engineer's wife must necessarily be the active manager of every thing related to household concerns. So as for arrangements you can & must make them to suit yourself.
Engineer's Arrangements are however you know, at the best, only temporary, and often obliged to live, and be contented to live almost any how, especially at the west.

 Well it is time this letter was finished.

I shall write as soon as I have any news to write about our business, and if there is news of importance, try at least to come myself and bring it. At any rate write often and hope you will do the same.  With much love to Father & Mother, and especially to yourself.

                                                                                                          Sincerely,
                                                                                                                      I.S.
Completed

Jonesboro, Union Co. Ill.

                   Jonesboro Union Co. Ill. 
                  March 1 1852
                                                                                                                       Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                                                               March 14, 1852

Dear Antoinette

                                 This is a beautiful, very beautiful, Sabbath Morning. It is a real Spring Morning, such an one as can be expected in New Hampshire or Maine sometime in May, perhaps hardly till towards the last of the months though!

As I sit here I look from my window and see - the one side to be sure the old rusty Court house and the Public Square ankle-deep with mud from yesterday's rain - but on the other a garden with long rows of vegetables bursting from the Earth, various shrubbery in full leaf, bright grass flats etc.; in the distance on the one side a mighty forest whose grand old trees stretch their giant limbs against the rising sun, some of them even beginning to glow with the hues of Spring; on the other side stretch away broad bright wheat fields already  almost waving in the breeze. Does not even that description give you an idea of spring? One quite different from that of March in New Hampshire. You will think my window must be a very pleasant one. So indeed it would be, if what I have described were all; but in fact, all that is only seen in glimpses through among & over the various dirty dingy looking, unpainted buildings, some of logs half hewed, some of warped & twisted boards, some with big ill looking old chimneys on the outside, and some with big ill-looking old chimneys on the outside, and some without; but I believe all decidedly ill looking and disorderly.
Completed

your good letter of Feb. 27 came safely to hand last evening and a little one of Feb. 21, a day or two before; two letters for me too in one week, and much it pleased me too.
I thank you heartily for endeavoring to comfort "Engineers on Central Rail Roads'. on their manifold troubles and trials of patience. The Clouds 'beautifully tinged with sunshine' are certainly encouraging.
Your reading Circle must be, as I can very well perceive very interesting, and very profitable, if the Readings are well selected, which I judge from the examples you gave, they probably are.

 The Methodist Circuit preacher Mr. Rogers preached this forenoon, and really very well, upon "The Way, the truth & the life." Mr. Rogers' sermons are really very good, methodically & argumentatively arranged for one who preaches without notes; but are very much injured by his slow, hesitating and imperfect delivery. His sermons are intrinsically very much superior to those of the little fluent Baptist preachers here, who is so much admired by most of the people.

You enquire when and where I was near being a Methodist, and what prevented.
It was ten years ago. In the winter of 1841-2 I was teaching school in the little Town of Brownville Piscataquis Co. Main. It was there that, as I hope. I first submitted my heart to Christ. There was a small Congregational Church there, but the Revival I think commenced among the Methodists. There was the best feeling between the two denominations. Meetings were frequently at least Alternate, and all
Completed

attended each.Those Methodist Meetings were interesting indeed, full of zeal & love. My prejudices had all been the other way; but I did love those Methodists. I left Brownville early in the Spring, and spent the Summer in Exeter Maine. There was then no Congregational Church in Exeter. Mr. Cutler, John Cutler, with whom I lived, an hereditary friend of our family, from Royalston Mass. and a noble specimen of a man, was a Methodist, a real old fashioned Wesleyan Methodist. Exeter was a great stronghold of the Methodists. Their preachers there, I remember with admiration. They were Mighty Men, men of strong frames and strong minds, with great warm hearts, bold and full of zeal. I certainly came very near being a Methodist. Le me do the Methodists Justice. I did not perceive there among them, not have I elsewhere or since, perceived among them as I certainly think I have among Baptists an unworthy spirit of proselytism {if it is a proper word} from other denominations. Their proselyting is from the ranks of sin & sinners, from the camps of the enemy not from those of their Allies. That, would at that time I believe have most effectually turned me from them. I remember, when, my Congregational friends I suppose thinking I was about to become a Methodist, a certain Cong. Minister took me in hand in a proselyting spirit to argue certain doctrines etc. I know he almost made me a Methodist at once!
I became a Congregationalist I believe simply and solely upon the question of Church Government. I should perhaps as readily have become a Methodist as even a Presbyterian. I certainly did not then, perhaps do hardly still, though my Metaphysical perceptions on those points have been very much strengthened & enforced, & my own opinions
Completed

very much confirmed, since then, by many, almost night long discussions & disquistions with a certain Methodist College friend & sometime Chum of mine (Such arguments you know almost always have a powerful effect in confirming & strengthening one's own views and tenets upon any subject) I did not then, do hardly yet perceive the necessary vital, essential, difference in the creed of these denominations. The most zealous Arminian will allow the absolute perfect infinity of God. The most rigid Calvinist calls Man a free agent. And so I am willing to let the matter rest between them.
By the way there seems to be a little too much of hard feeling between the Presbyterians & Congregationalists just now, Originating partly perhaps in some spirit of proselyting in this great Western field.
Well, it is time for me to stop writing.
My health is good. My work abundant but pleasant. 
It appears pretty certain that the work here is going on vigorously this summer. All are busy as possible making every preparation, and no one can get away now.
How I early I shall be able to get away next Summer I cannot yet tell.

                             With much love
                                      Sincerely
                                                 I.S.
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro Union Co. Ill.
April 5 1852

                                                                                 Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                 Sabbath Afternoon April 4, 1852

Dear Antoinette

                 I do not know but you will think it strange to see my letters usually dated on the Sabbath. I have usually but very little time to spare from business upon other days. Especially as I finish entirely upon week days many kinds of business that other Engineers habitually perform on the Sabbath. Then there is no such thing in this country as a Afternoon Meeting. Services are universally at 11 A.M. and in the evening. So the Afternoon is spent by all classes, members of the Churches as well as others in walking or riding about, visiting etc. Even the Clergymen do the same, at any rate,  keep open house on Sabbath Afternoon, and invite any one to call at that time specially. My New England habits & feelings prejudices they would be called here, do not exactly permit this though I am probably entirely alone in the whole region in uniformly refusing all invitations to walk, ride, or visit on the Sabbath.  So you see I am quite a Solitary, and have a long Sabbath Afternoon every week, entirely to myself, and a very fine time it is to read, or to write letters to Mother, brothers, Sisters, and you.
 Your letter of March 13, was joyfully received  on Apr. 1. with at the same time letters from Bangor. Mother, brothers & Sisters. I have been a good deal troubled for a week past having
Completed

heard by letter a week since that my Youngest brother, who has been the past winter at School of East Hampton Mass. was quite sick. A letter received yesterday relieve my mind very much. He had gone to Dr. Munde's Water Cure Establishment at NorthHampton, had got better, and was about returning to Bangor.  I was the more alarmed about it as his disease was occasioned by an injury something like that which produced dear Joseph's disease. I perhaps wrote to you about his getting hurt last winter a year ago. I suppose it likely that he saved the lives of a couple of girls by throwing himself against a runaway horse which tried to jump over the sleigh in which he and the girls were riding. The force of the blow was so great as to crush into fragments the sleigh even though the horse himself did not touch it at all, being fairly crowded aside by my brother's shoulders. His back was hurt however, and has been lame ever since until a few weeks ago he was attacked with violent pain in the back & acute inflamation of the kidneys, occasioned the doctors say by the same injury a year since. I hope now, this being thrown off, that he may experience no further ill from it.

 We here at last received the long expected action of the Ill. Central R.R. Co. They have been long delayed by difficulties in obtaining the title to the lands granted them by Government, difficulties at the Land Office which I hardly understand, And which matters were not finally settled till sometime in March. The Orders have just reached us two or three days since On account of the delay, bringing it later in the Season, the work in the North part of the State is to be started before this
Completed

Southern Division. Three hundred miles of the Road is already (March 25) advertized for Contracts. But this Division by the new arrangement is not to be put under Contract until the last of May, and then I think it most probable that there will really be but little work accomplished until the heat of Summer is past, till about September perhaps.
So we are not likely to be over hurried with business, although there is considerable work laid out for us to do for a while now. I cannot tell yet when I shall be able to go East though. Perhaps in a month or so, Maybe even less. It appears very probably that I may be wanted to go up into the Northern part of the State this Summer, as that work is going on first. But I shall not probably know until Col. Mason gets around here. I shall hardly want to leave here when I have spent much effort to try to have my work comfortably arranged and to suit me. Still, it would hardly do to refuse, if I am offered a better situation there. However I may not have the chance. They may decide I shall be wanted here eventually. Well - I will keep you advised of what ever does happen, and of the probabilities of the future as fast as I do learn what they are.

 We have had quite a spell of cold Weather here. unusual people call it. Vegetation has not seemed to advance hardly at all for weeks. In fact I think March has been colder than February was, and the season is now considered quite backward.

Flowers are abundant though in the woods as N.E. May or June.
Completed

[Post mark]JONESBOROUGH ILL APR 5
Miss Antoinette B. Putnam

  Dunbarton
             N.H.
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro Union Co.

                      Illinois

April 19 1852

                                                                                       Jonesboro, Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                      Sabbath Eve, April 18, 1852

Dear Antoinette

                It is just ten o clock P.M. I have just returned from Meeting, which was quite unusually protracted to night. But I think I must wrote a bit of a letter to you before I go to sleep. Sabbath day you know is my day to write letters to you and my Mother. And if I do not do it tonight, I might neglect in among the business of the week.

The Methodists have had a Sabbath School Convention here in Jonesboro today, commenced on Friday last. There are an abundance of their preachers, both local and itinerant from all this part of the State present here.
Some of them preach pretty well, and some of them call for some slight exercise of Charity I think.  The one who preached this evening, A Tailor from Nottingham England, a Local preacher at Marion in this State I liked pretty well. Plainly without advantages of early education, he is evidently a student, probably a hard student, and being young, I consider really promising. One very serious fault though he had tonight he tried to speak too long; it seemed almost two hours, and was certainly an hour too long!
I have heard three sermons preached today which is something quite unusual here, besides attending Lore? feast, and hearing various speeches and exhortations from the different preachers and others who had been present
Completed

Your letter of March 27 was gladly received a day or two since. It was longer in the way than usual some letters have been only about 10 days on the road. For a week or two past the Mails have been very irregular, and in all last week We had but one Eastern Mail I think. 
You write of having another winter in March. It has been about so here. Warm weather came on the last of January. February I think was warmer than I ever knew April at the East: it seemed most like May. Vegetation seemed to starting very rapidly. But about the first of March winter seemed to come again about a winter fit for this climate. Cold, win, rain, and frost. Vegetation seemed to stop and stand still almost for six weeks. Some early leaves which had been coming out fell off and others have been from then until now in getting fairly out; so with the blossoms of the fruit trees etc. etc.

It has seemed very strange. I suppose vegetation always starts very slowly here compared with the North where every plant and tree seems to realize that its season is short. Some Spring flowers which are common to both climates, and which at the North are in blossom  as soon as the snow is fairly off are here hardly out now where there has been no snow for almost three months. I suppose the plants have just such a time to perfect themselves, forming their roots etc. and come out at about the same time of year in all climates.

 I am glad to hear that your Reading Circle prospers so well. I think it must be quite useful as well as agreeable.
Completed

Pilgrim's Progress in the Nineteenth Century I have not read, but want to.

 I was never so destitute of books, or of the possibility of getting books as since I have been out here. In fact I have read less since out here than I think ever before. I brought no books with me, and there are none to be got at here. If I ever got to the East again, or where there are books, I will not come back I think without a supply lain in.
 I do think now that I shall go east next month in May. I am by no means hurried with work now, and feel rather bad that I cannot get away, but cannot leave here very well till Col. Mason comes here which will be early in May.

The Work on this Division is to be let the last of May, and there will be little to do here except what we are fast doing up until after that time. So I think O can go the. But I must remain and see Col. Mason. There is some talk of putting me in charge of a Division up in the Prairies toward the north part of the State. Champaign Co. perhaps, and I am obliged to wait & see him. I hardly wish really to make the change, although a promotion and increase of salary I suppose. I have got things so well arranged here, and every thing is so good order for a comfortable season on this work, on which moreover is greater choice for improvement as an Engineer, than upon the Prairie country at the North. This the "Land of Egypt" as the call Southern Illinois , is almost as barbarous
Completed

country, only about half civilized at any rate.
And at the north is almost a desert, - no not a desert for I suppose it is one of the most fertile regions on the glove: but there is a region there almost entirely unopened: the rail road will make it really accessible for the first time.
There is said to be more than sixty miles there in one stretch where the RailRoad line does not pass the Shadow of a tree! And about twenty miles in one place without a house! 
What do you think of that?

 Did I write you that brother Eliab was sick? He is better, and I suppose at Bangor, but I have not heard from him since he arrived there. I have been anxiously expecting a letter for a week past from him.
 Well it is getting late, I must bring this unwieldly letter to a close.
 With much of love to you and yours,
                                               Sincerely
                                                               I.S.

Miss Antoinette B. Putnam
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro Union Co.
April 15 1852   Illinois           

                                                                                                 Jonesboro Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                                  Sabbath, April 15, 1852

Dear Antoinette

                                Your letter of April 18 came to hand yesterday, and at the same time with letters mailed in March, from friends both in Maine & Minnesota.
 You enquire if Boston was not my Native place. I was born in Royalston, Worcester Country Mass. which was also my Father's Native place, and where he always owned property, a house and farm at least, which were sold after his death. Before his death I had lived part of the time in Royalston and part of the time in Boston. But after his death, and before I was ten years old, my brother and family moved away into Maine, where my oldest brother had already established himself.

Your Fast Day sermon must have been quite an interesting one I think. We have upon this RailRoad several Engineers who are political refugees from Europe.
Their histories of '48 & '50, and their hopes and aspirations for the future of their countries are quite interesting. They were of the class of men, young men, who were active and the leaders of Europe in 1848. One is a young Pole, who served as a huzzar officer in Hungary. Another is a Prussian, who was in Government service as R.R. engineer, but was one of the leaders of popular revolution in Berlin in '48.
Completed

They were ardent enthusiasts in the cause of Liberty, but, like most perhaps of these fellows too far from the earnest religious faiths of Kossuth.
Young Europe, as it is sometimes called, is, I fear, now too much in religion and morality like the French of the old French Revolution. It is quite natural however, especially for young men like the German revolutionists. They have got their eyes fully open to the giant wrongs and almost unnumbered abuses of their present systems, both civil and religious, and are very liable in their enthusiasm to endeavor to tear down every timeworn institution and rusty bulwark which they fancy in the way of their proposed developement. It cannot be expected that all would see as clearly as Kossuth does, that the true unalloyed religion of Jesus Christ is and must necessarily be ever on the side of true liberty and human right.
I have a great enthusiasm for Kossuth. My admiration of him, I believe, has no drawback. Elgin Kossuth!

  You have doubtless heard the new Word is so common in politics lately - "Old Fogies." I could not help thinking of it during sermon this forenoon. The very large Baptist Church here is very much divided. The large portion, I do not know but a Majority, are almost of the old "Regular" stripe. What they call among the Baptists in this Country "Regulars" or "Ironsides", are noted by their "Forkish"? belief in the question of Election, and their most bitter opposition to Temperance and every species of Missionary Effort or Reform. But their Minister
Completed

who came here last fall, his predecessor being obliged to leave because he joined the Sons of Temperance} is a young man of the progressive kind in respect to Temperance Missions, Sabbath Schools etc. with considerable talent & energy, and disposition, to use them.
This forenoon he certainly carried the war into the very camp of the "Old Fogies", on temperance and missions, in an extremely venturesome manner for a man in his situation.
Intemperance has been until a year or two almost universal in this region; and among Church Members & even Ministers too as well as elsewhere. Here in Jonesboro, Ministers have but a few years ago stopped at the Grocery for a Dram, both on the way to and from Meeting on the Sabbath!

  My beautiful horse is dead. I care much more than his worth. It was really affecting to see him in his sickness follow me around to lean his head against my shoulder, and even as he lay on the ground he would reach his head round to get it against me.
 I suppose he was poisoned by accidentally eating among his feed of grain at Murphysboro a few days since, a few "Castor beans". seeds of the Castor Oil plant, which are raised here, and which are supposed extremely fatal to horses. He was as well as ever and as full of life & spirit as his skin could hold, last Wednesday morning, at Murphysboro. He was taken sick before I got back here, suffered very much, and dead the next Afternoon.
Completed

My Colt was one of excelled qualities and much promise; and I believe I should as lief have lost a hundred dollars in almost any other way.

    The people of Jonesboro are re-awaking upon the subject of Temperance just now. And well they may, for if nothing is done to prevent, with their present laws & prospective circumstances, they would while this Rail Road is building almost fall back into their old State. They are just forming a Division of the Sons of Temperance here, and making some effort to stop and save some of the young men who are so much in danger. I believe I have and have had some influence for good in the Temperance Cause here since I have been here.
 If my letters are not worth much, you must agree that they are written pretty often. So I will stop for now.
                                Love to all
                                                 Sincerely
                                                            I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro Union Co.

  May 10 1852
                                                                                               Jonesboro. Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                               Sabbath, May 9, 1852

Dear Antoinette

                 It seems some time since I have received a letter from you. I fear there has been a Mail lost with letters for me. The Mails have been very irregular lately, occasioned, I suppose, by heavy rains and high water. The Eastern Newspapers for one week we have failed entirely of receiving. Last Sunday night and Monday Morning was the greatest storm I ever saw. I believe there is never any thing like it in New England. It was really almost dreadfully magnificent. There seemed to be one continual rolling peal of thunder, and one constant uninterrupted flash of lightning, and such torrents of rain!  There was considerable damage done, as once before this spring, by the washing away of fences, destruction of roads, bridges and crops. In some places considerable injury was done to cattle and crops by hail. A few miles from here one man was drowned in trying to ford a bit of brook near his house. This Afternoon is has rained about in the same way though without the thunder and lightning. Our old German Lutheran Father Krack preached today, and a most excellent sermon too, up the first four verses of 1 Cor. 10.
Completed

It was really one of the ablest sermons I have heard since I have been out here, perhaps though slightly clouded in parts by some German mystical Metaphysics. Not that I believe the old gentleman intends to preach any thing but Christ & him crucified, {which he certainly does most plainly and thoroughly}, but then he very naturally thinks in German.

  This evening there is no meeting in Town on account of the great Rain.
 We have lately got started here a New Morning Sabbath School; Union of all Denominations, Bap. Meth. and German. I have taken charge of a Bible Class of Young Men, with the understanding that when I am absent the Baptist Minister shall take my place. The school bids fair to become quite interesting. It has only now been in operation two weeks.
 I wish you could be here now to witness the beauty of the vegetation and the forest scenery at the present time. There is certainly a richness and fullness, a magnificence in the foliage here which is unknown farther north. I never saw anything which could compare with the forests here now.

The Redbud and the Crab Apple here done flowering; but the flowering Dogwood, and the Viburnums are still in their beauty, and form a most admirable Substratum of White beneath the massive piles of green foliage of the more towering trees. The Tulip Tree, Poplar they call it here, is one of the most common through this region, and is certainly one of the
Completed

most magnificent of trees. I do not know as I ever saw its Equal. The Liquid Amber, or Sweet Gum is also a most splendid tree.
This is certainly one of the most beautiful countries in the World. I can now appreciate its beauties much better than I could last fall,when writhing under the ague, which I believe makes everything appear bad and miserable.  I never saw so beautiful an uncultivated country as this now is, among these hills, such a wealth and exuberance of vegetation, so great a variety of surface & scenery. 
I was visiting some romantic places last week near our R.R. line; the Drury Creek Valley, a gorge among the Sandstone hills, through which our Road is to pass. Some times the hills rising up immediately on either side one or two hundred feet, then again spreading out into little flowery valleys, with the brook branches coming down on either side through little narrow gorges in the sandstone cliffs, which rise on either side perhaps 20, 50 or 100 feet, perpendicular, or overhanging, full to of little caves and crevices and water springs, and the flowers, flowers every where, among the fine old trees.

 We have found too subject of interest for Antiquarian as well as Botanist & Geological in the same region; the remains of an old fortification on one of the hill points running out into Drury Valley. The point extending into the Valley is a Cliff, perpendicular or overhanging, for twenty to fifty ft. high. the top smooth & level, inaccessible except by a narrow neck, across which are the remains of a Massive stone wall.
Completed

It is of great antiquity, but like no work of the Indians. I am inclined to think it was built by the Spanish Expedition under De Soto, more than three hundred years since. They might have stopped there, searching among these hills for precious metals, and warring with the Indians.
There are also appearances of ancient mining in this region.
The Spring is a beautiful season in this Climate. You know perhaps I have never shared much in the enthusiasm of admiring the Spring as it is in New England, preferring the Autumn or even Winter of N.E. to the Spring.
But here I give it up. I have never seen so delightful weather as the Spring of Southern Illinois. It is not so bracing and enlivening as our N.E. Autumn, which I have always thought the finest weather in the world, but there is a purity & beauty in the atmosphere here. I think it must be like the Climate of Italy, where it is said one wants no other enjoyment than to breathe out of doors. In N.E. Autumn the enjoyment is in life & activity. here in quiet laziness in the serene atmosphere.
You must not think from this that I have yet become quite a Sucker. I believe there is till some old New England life & feeling left in me. With much love to all and yourself particularly And hoping to hear from you very soon

                                                                             Sincerely
                                                                                         I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac Jonesboro Union Co
May 28, 1852   Illinois

                                                                          Jonesboro Union Co. Illinois
                                                                                   May 28, 1852

Dear Antoinette

           Your letter of May 13 was received with much pleasure on yesterday.

I shall not attempt to write a letter today, as I am just leaving here for Down East.

 We are not likely to do much here for some time, probably till near Fall. I am pretty well tired of remaining here idle, and think I can enjoy myself better elsewhere. And as I have finished up every thing I have to do until the Grading Commences, I am expecting that my salary will go on just the same while I am absent, as if I were here all the time.

But do not be expecting me as soon as you get this letter. I have got a freak in my mind to travel part of the way, over through Indiana on horseback, which, you know is slow compared with Railways & Steamboats. I have got a fine horse all ready, and shall start in half an hour.

 I will write to you probably on the way, and may not reach New England
Completed

until near the first of July.
I expect to enjoy the ride across the country at this season very much.

 Being in haste, I must stop writing.

With much love & best wishes.

                            Sincerely,
                                     I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac  Columbus

               Bartholemew Co.

June 7 1852

                                                                      Columbus, Bartholemew Co. Ind.
                                                                       Sabbath June 6, 1852

Dear Antoinette

                             I wrote I believe a hasty scrawl to you just as I started from Jonesboro, week before the last. So you will not be surprise to hear of me at most any where I suppose.

I have had a fine Journey so far, no very remarkable adventures, but a good deal of the quiet enjoyment of travelling.  One misfortune I met with though.
The horse I started with, quite a valuable one, was taken sick on the road, with the distemper it is called. I was afraid I should lose him, and at any rate I could not bear to wait in the miserable place for him to get well. So my made my first effort at the Yankee accomplishment of "swapping". and traded off my beautiful, but sick horse for an old codger which carries me along tolerably well, slowly, and which I can at least give away when I get tired of riding. I have come through Union, Williamson, Franklin, Hamilton & White Counties. Illinois; and Posey, Gibson, Pike, Davies, Martin, Lawrence, Jackson, Brown & Bartholemew in this State. The first Sabbath I spent at Carmi,  White Co. Ill. and heard both a Methodist and a HardSide Baptist preach powerfully in the Old Court House. This Morning I rode ten or twelve miles to Church! To get here to
Completed

Columbus, where, for the first time for nearly a year I heard the sound of the Sabbath. Only think of that. You can hardly imagine how good it sounded this morning. The last Sabbath that I heard a church bell was I think last June at Springfield Ill. The week before at Chicago, the week before that at Westfield, New York.
Rev. Mr. Brownlow the Presbyterian minister whom I heard preach this forenoon, is a very fine portly looking gentleman, would look very well for a City D.D. almost any where. He preached very well too, he is an Eastern Man, though he he enlarged upon the rich "bottom" lands about Sodom, which Lot was so well pleased with.  His text was the separation of Abraham & Lot, and Lot's choice of the Plains of Jordan. By the way, though, I thought, considering the reputation Columbus now has that he ought to have been a little more explicit in his advice to his people; if they found themselves already located in Sodom. Columbus has established the character of a "hard place", I believe. There was a most brutal unprovoked murder here not long since by a gang of miscreants which have long harbored here.

 I stopped a day or so at the Great Sulphur Springs in Martin Co. They are called the largest Mineral Springs in the world, the streams from them is almost a Mill Stream. Their Medicinal qualities are highly recommended, and they have several hundred visitors every summer.

I really think that the Sulphur water I frank while there did me good! gave me appetite etc.
Completed

I came through New Harmony on the Wabash, where the German Colony, disciples of Rapp. were settled first. Since at Economy Penn. You have probably read something of them. Memorials of them are still seen at New Harmony, in many very large old fashioned hipped roofed brick buildings, in the beautiful fields, and, good roads, which they planned and built. Rapp himself must be a remarkable man. The present worth of their property at Economy is reckoned by Millions almost.
 The Country that I have come through in this State is most of the way very beautiful, and improving in wealth & population very rapidly indeed. Along near White Rover though is a very sickly country. In place there is even the horrible Milk sickness, which I think is most to be dreaded of all diseases.
 I believe I shall keep on in my present style of journeying a while longer, over into Ohio at least. I enjoy it very much so far. So I can hardly tell where I shall go; or when I shall get there!
 I will write occasionally.
                                                 Sincerely
                                               I. S. Metcalf
Completed

[post mark] COLUMBUS  Ind. JUN 7                                                            PAID

                                  Miss Antoinette B. Putnam
                                              Dunbarton
                                                    N.H.

Isaac Columbus Bartholemew Col.
Cincinnati Ohio 
June 19, 1852                                      Columbus, Bartholemew County

                                                              Indiana, Friday June 18. 1852

Dear Antoinette

                      I wrote to you most a fortnight ago from this same place.

Since then I have been but about fifteen miles from here, and returned last night.
Soon after leaving here Monday morning June 7, I was taken sick. I finally reached a little Village, called Hartsville, in the North East Corner of the Country, about fifteen miles from here, and there I laid at a little country tavern, fairly on my face, for about ten days! It was only day before yesterday that I got fairly upon my feet. Yesterday I got a man to bring me down here in a carraige, and today I believe I am about as well as common, only not quite as stout.

 You may imagine that I had need of all my patience, philosophy and other gentler virtues, or graces, to get along in such condition and in such a place. In fact my endurance really astonished myself, especially considering that I suffered a good deal of pain, restlessness and sleeplessness occasioned by the sickness.

My sickness was occasioned by a complaint that I knew nothing of, had never heard of, and could not at first understand, occasioned merely by too much riding horseback. I find since that it is not unusual, and is well understood by those who ride on horseback very much, and by Cavalry soldiers in army etc.
Completed

I suffered a good deal of pain, for more than I ever knew anything about before: But I might have been a good deal worse off. There were some kind people there, the Sons of Temperance came) looked after me, and the Doctor whom I found there was a very pleasant and kind man.

 So on the whole my sickness was nothing very bad. Nothing that can hurt me permanently, only ten days and cost me but whole twenty dollars. It was the first time I ever really suffered pain, and I shall now I believe how to prize exemption from it in future:
As you may suppose I am not much inclined to try horseback riding again at once.

I sold my horse and equipment at Hartsville, and came back here.

I intend to go to Madison, by the Madison and Indianapolis R.R., which passes through this place, this afternoon. From there the Steamboats, which run in connection with the cars will take me to Cincinnata in twelve hours. I intend to stop in Cincinnati over the Sabbath. And from there I suppose could be any where in New England in a day or a few days or two. However, my sister Anne's vacation at Westfield commences the first of July. I suppose she would like to have me to go East with her.

So I may turn aside next week and make a visit to Zanesville, Ohio, where I have some Relatives, and reach Westfield about July 1st.

 I shall expect to find letters for me at Westfield both from You, friends at Bangor & from Illinois.
                                                                                      Sincerely, 
                                                                                           I.S.M.
Completed

Big Muddy Store
                                                                                                     April 1st '53
                                                                                                           12 M.

Dearest Ettie

                    I have just this minute received a note from Col. R.R. Mason who is at Jonesboro, and wishes me to be there as soon as possible I suppose I must go right down from here this afternoon, and probably shall not be at home till some time next wek.

This is a hard fate but cannot well be avoided.
Mr. Mason will probably not be here for a month or more.

Mr. Ashley's children are very sick with the Measles. When this Messenger left it was thought that John would not live.

I shall probably remain with Col. Mason till Monday night or Tuesday.
So do not expect me till I come for it maybe longer.
Do take special care of my Ettie while I am gone. Get Lizzie or Miss Paine to sleep with you etc.
I am in haste,   Aff.  I S.
Completed

P.S. It might be well for you if convenient to go down to the Office and bring up to the house & keep safely those vouchers valuable papers which you will find in my desk, - on right hand side.
Mr. Holt will want nothing from them in my absence
I.S.
[right-hand side] Isaac April 1/53

? N. York, May 30 - 1854
Bangor June 2 - 1854

                                                                                      Astor House, N.Y. <May 20th

Dearest Ettie

   I believe I promised to write sometime. This is my first stop.

In haste now.
Unpleasant time aboard Bangor Boat Awful Crowd; about the worst looking set of 'humans' I ever fell among. About half of them - yes, 9/10 I should think were simply going up to Boston for a drink of Whiskey. No state rooms either; so one is necessarily in the crowd.
When you go, go any way but on a Boston Boat without securing at least a good state room long beforehand -And then carry yr own provisions without there is improvement since I was there.
There was hardly room seen to stand up any where on the boat.
Arrived at Boston near Nine A.M. 
Here to night tired & dirty: but in good health & spirits.  Take care of my Ettie & Baby.
Most affectionately

                                       I.S.  ~
Completed
Enclosed is a present you may make to Eliab  or Samuel & Eliab
